cards.back: The spontaneous decay of an unstable atomic nucleus, accompanied by the emission of radiation.

cards.front: What are the characteristics of **Alpha (α) particles**?
cards.back: Composed of 2 protons and 2 neutrons (a Helium nucleus: $^4_2He$); they have a $+2$ charge and low penetrating power.

cards.front: What are the characteristics of **Beta (β) particles**?
cards.back: High-speed electrons ($^0_{-1}e$) emitted when a neutron turns into a proton; they have a $-1$ charge and moderate penetrating power.
High-energy electromagnetic radiation with no mass or charge; they have the highest penetrating power.

cards.front: What is a **half-life ($t_{1/2}$)** in nuclear decay?
cards.back: The time required for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay.
The splitting of a heavy nucleus into two lighter nuclei, releasing a massive amount of energy (used in nuclear power plants).
The combining of two light nuclei to form a heavier, more stable nucleus; it powers stars but requires extreme temperatures.
The difference between the mass of an atom and the sum of the masses of its individual nucleons; this mass is converted into binding energy ($E=mc^2$).
The conversion of an atom of one element into an atom of another element through nuclear decay or bombardment.
The tendency of atoms to prefer to have eight electrons in the valence shell to achieve stability.
If a system at equilibrium is disturbed, the system will shift its equilibrium position to counteract the disturbance.
The measure of the ability of an atom in a chemical compound to attract electrons.

cards.front: Review: What is the **Ideal Gas Law** equation?

cards.back: A substance that can donate a pair of electrons to form a covalent bond.
Moles of solute per liter of solution ($M = n/V$).
